subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: I think I was carried away yesterday for all the discussions (and sorry about the mistake on Tryon s name. :)  ). Later I calmed down and thought it through
messageBody:
I think I was carried away yesterday for all the discussions (and sorry about
the mistake on Tryon's name. :) ).

Later I calmed down and thought it through and here is what I think.

First, I think I need to show you how exactly the tests are written in the XP
group I was in. So that you know where I am coming from.

After we have the stories, assigned the task cards, we sat down and started
coding. However, we don't exactly do the 'DESIGN' part. Sure we think of the
structure a little bit but we do that just to write down the steps that we need
to achieve in order to finish the task card in hand.

With the each step, which is normally a functionality we want to add into a
class, we write a test method to do waht we call 'break the code'. The test
would fail and the only way to pass it is to 'fix' the code, or actaully add the
new functionality we planned. Then on the second step we add another test to
break another part of the code (which can be another class), and then fix the
code the pass the test. This break-and-fix pattern keeps going untill all the
steps are finished.

So for this order example, say we have two classes to carry out the task: Order
class get an instance of Product class, which has all the product information.

Order ---- (uses) ---> Product

And to add the logic we want, we use TestOrder and MockProduct to test the Order
class, so it is now like this (how to 'trick' Order class into using MockProduct
is another story):

TestOrder --(uses)--> Order --- (uses) ---> MockProduct

So we add a testCreateOrder_Unavailable method, we set MockProduct to return
UNAVAILABLE whenever the getStatus is called, and then assert that an exception
is thrown when createOrder is called (or some other kind of errors). The test
will fail and the only way to 'fix' the code is to add the logic into Order
class.

So as you can see, we are concentrating on the Order class and this class only
for this test method. And that is why Order class itself is considered as a
unit. In this way, even if a bug is introduced later into Product class, the
tests for Order would never fail because it doesn't care what exactly the real
Product is. And if the tests for Order fail anytime, we would pretty much know
that it has to be in either the Order class implementation or the test methods
impletation.

Hopefully, I understand Tryon's way correctly, that is:

TestClass ---(uses)---> Order ---(uses)---> Product ---(uses)---> ...

So that's why you consider the whole module as a unit. The TestClass here is
supposed to test all the functionality (or all the possible result) from the
beginnig to the end. And I think that is what the AT(Acceptance Test) or
Functional Test is about.

My current group is also doing this way because we have a pretty good QA team
dedicated in writing those tests and the product is kind of too big to spend all
the development time on writing unit test for everything now.




Jason Tryon wrote:

> My premise is that the tests are the design, not simply related thereto. We
> have a list of possible results of creating an order. These possible
> outcomes determine the things we have to test. In creating the tests, we
> create the design. It then becomes the tests that drive the design rather
> than being a trailing afterthought to determine whether we anwered the
> requirements.
>
> Conventional Methodology:
>
> Requirements ----> Design ----> Construction ----> Testing -- -->
> Delivery
> ^ |
> |-----------< Revision of Design <-----|
>
> Suggested Methodology :
>
> Request ----> Tests ----> Design ----> Construction -- --> Delivery
> ^ |
> |---------< Revision of Tests <-------|
>
> By devising the tests before construction, a couple of things are gained.
> First, the request, tests and designs are closer together in the process.
> This improves communication and the reliability of the design. Second, the
> tests drive the development process instead of a logical design improving
> both the quality of the design and the answer the solution provides to the
> original request.
>
> Regards,
>
> Jason Tryon
>
> P.S. It's pronounced Try - on ... like to try on a hat. :)
